intro: Sorghum halepense var. schreberi, commonly known as Johnson grass, is a perennial grass native to the Mediterranean region but now widely naturalized in many parts of the world. It is characterized by its tall, erect stems and large, feather-like leaves that can reach lengths of up to 30 centimeters. The plant produces panicles of small, greenish-yellow flowers that develop into hard, cylindrical seed heads. Johnson grass is known for its rapid growth and ability to thrive in a variety of soil types, making it both a useful forage crop and a problematic weed. Its botanical features make it highly adaptable, contributing to its success in various environments.
